standard_metadata.standard_description: Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.

question.content: Elaine's jewelry box has a volume of $36$ cubic centimeters.  **Which of the following could be the dimensions of Elaine's jewelry box?**

options.content: $3\text{ cm}$ long, $4\text{ cm}$  wide, $3\text{ cm}$  high
$12\text{ cm}$  long, $12\text{ cm}$  wide, $12\text{ cm}$  high
$4\text{ cm}$  long, $4\text{ cm}$  wide, $2\text{ cm}$  high

hints.content: Volume of a rectangular prism can be found by using the formula $\text{Volume}=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}$.

Let's plug in the choices and see when we get a volume of $\green{36}$ cubic centimeters.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\pink3\times\pink4\times\pink3=\green{36}$     [[☃ image 2]]       $\gray4\times\gray4\times\gray2=\red{32}$     [[☃ image 3]]       $\blue{12}\times\blue{12}\times\blue{12}=\red{1{,}728}$

images.alt: A rectangular prism made up of centimeter cubes. The front face of the rectangular prism shows 9 cubes: 3 rows and 3 columns. The top face of the cube shows 12 cubes, 4 rows and 3 columns. The right-hand side face shows 12 cubes: 3 rows and 4 columns. The length of the rectangular prism is 3 centimeters. The width of the rectangular prism is 4 centimeters. The height of the rectangular prism is 3 centimeters.

A rectangular prism made up of centimeter cubes. The front face of the rectangular prism shows 8 cubes: 2 rows and 4 columns. The top face of the cube shows 16 cubes, 4 rows and 4 columns. The right-hand side face shows 8 cubes: 2 rows and 4 columns. The length of the rectangular prism is 4 centimeters. The width of the rectangular prism is 4 centimeters. The height of the rectangular prism is 2 centimeters.

A rectangular prism made up of centimeter cubes. The front face of the rectangular prism shows 144 cubes: 12 rows and 12 columns. The top face of the cube shows 144 cubes, 12 rows and 12 columns. The right-hand side face shows 144 cubes: 12 rows and 12 columns. The length of the rectangular prism is 12 centimeters. The width of the rectangular prism is 12 centimeters. The height of the rectangular prism is 12 centimeters.

hints.content: The dimensions of Elaine's jewelry box could be the following:  - $3\text{ cm}$ long, $4\text{ cm}$  wide, $3\text{ cm}$  high

question.content: I bought a box from the post office that has a volume of $24$ cubic centimeters.  **Which of the following could be the dimensions of my box?**

options.content: $2\text{ cm}$ long, $2\text{ cm}$  wide, $6\text{ cm}$  high
$8\text{ cm}$ long, $1\text{ cm}$  wide, $3\text{ cm}$  high
$10\text{ cm}$  long, $4\text{ cm}$  wide, $10\text{ cm}$  high

hints.content: Volume of a rectangular prism can be found by using the formula $\text{Volume}=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}$.

Let's plug in the choices and see when we get a volume of $\green{24}$ cubic centimeters.   [[☃ image 1]]    $\pink2\times\pink2\times\pink6=\green{24}$     [[☃ image 2]]       $\gray8\times\gray1\times\gray3=\green{24}$     [[☃ image 3]]       $\blue{10}\times\blue{4}\times\blue{10}=\red{400}$

hints.content: The dimensions of my box could be the following:  - $2\text{ cm}$ long, $2\text{ cm}$  wide, $6\text{ cm}$  high - $8\text{ cm}$ long, $1\text{ cm}$  wide, $3\text{ cm}$  high

question.content: Max's pet worm lives in a cardboard box that has a volume of $80$ cubic centimeters.  **Which of the following could be the dimensions of Max's box?**

options.content: $10\text{ cm}$ long, $4\text{ cm}$  wide, $2\text{ cm}$  high
$4\text{ cm}$  long, $5\text{ cm}$  wide, $4\text{ cm}$  high
$2\text{ cm}$  long, $5\text{ cm}$  wide, $8\text{ cm}$  high

hints.content: Volume of a rectangular prism can be found by using the formula $\text{Volume}=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}$.

Let's plug in the choices and see when we get a volume of $\green{80}$ cubic centimeters.   [[☃ image 1]]     $\pink4\times\pink5\times\pink4=\green{80}$    [[☃ image 2]]       $\gray2\times\gray5\times\gray8=\green{80}$     [[☃ image 3]]      $\blue{10}\times\blue{4}\times\blue{2}=\green{80}$

question.content: A box of granola bars has a volume of $210$ cubic centimeters.  **Which of the following could be the dimensions of the box?**

options.content: $15\text{ cm}$ long, $2\text{ cm}$  wide, $7\text{ cm}$  high
$7\text{ cm}$  long, $3\text{ cm}$  wide, $10\text{ cm}$  high
$14\text{ cm}$  long, $3\text{ cm}$  wide, $7\text{ cm}$  high

hints.content: Volume of a rectangular prism can be found by using the formula $\text{Volume}=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}$.

Let's plug in the choices and see when we get a volume of $\green{210}$ cubic centimeters.  [[☃ image 1]]     $\pink{15}\times\pink2\times\pink7=\green{210}$    [[☃ image 2]]      $\gray7\times\gray3\times\gray{10}=\green{210}$     [[☃ image 3]]    $\blue{14}\times\blue{3}\times\blue{7}=\red{294}$

hints.content: The dimensions of the box could be the following:  - $15\text{ cm}$ long, $2\text{ cm}$  wide, $7\text{ cm}$  high - $7\text{ cm}$ long, $3\text{ cm}$  wide, $10\text{ cm}$  high

question.content: A pool is filled with $270$ cubic meters of water.    The base of the pool is  $15\text{ m}$  long and $9\text{ m}$ wide.     **What is the height of the water in the pool?**     $\text {m}$

hints.content: Volume can be found using the formula $\purpleD{\text{Volume}}=\maroonD{\text{length}}\times \blueD{\text{width}}\times \greenD{\text{height}}$.

Let's plug in all the numbers we know:  $\purpleD{270}=\maroonD{15}\times\blueD{9}\times{}\greenD{?}$  $\purpleD{270}=135\times{}\greenD{?}$  What number can we multiply by $135$ to get $\purpleD{270}?$
$\purpleD{270}=135\times\greenD{2}$  The height of the water in the pool is $\greenD{2}$ meters.

question.content: Layla wants to build a wooden box with a volume of $45$ cubic centimeters.    She started with a width of $ 3\text{ cm}$  and a height of $ 3\text{ cm}$.     **How long should Layla make the box?**     $\text {cm}$

hints.content: Volume can be found using the formula $\purpleD{\text{Volume}}=\maroonD{\text{length}}\times \blueD{\text{width}}\times \greenD{\text{height}}$.
Let's plug in all the numbers we know:  $\purpleD{45}=\greenD{\,?}\times\blueD{3}\times\maroonD{3}$  $\purpleD{45}=\greenD{\,?}\times9$  What number can we multiply by $9$ to get $\purpleD{45}?$
$\purpleD{45}=\greenD5\times9$  Layla should make the box $\greenD5$ centimeters long.

question.content: I have to build a box for my scouting project with a volume of $36$ cubic centimeters.    The base of the box is  $ 6\text{ cm}$  long and $ 2\text{ cm}$ wide.     **How high should I build the box?**     $\text {cm}$

hints.content: Volume can be found using the formula $\purpleD{\text{Volume}}=\maroonD{\text{length}}\times \blueD{\text{width}}\times \greenD{\text{height}}$.
Let's plug in all the numbers we know:  $\purpleD{36}=\maroonD{6}\times\blueD{2}\times{}\greenD{?}$  $\purpleD{36}=12\times{}\greenD{?}$  What number can we multiply by $12$ to get $\purpleD{36}?$
$\purpleD{36}=12\times\greenD{3}$  The height of the box should be $\green3$ centimeters.

question.content: Nemo's aquarium is filled with $2{,}400$ cubic centimeters of water.    The base of the aquarium is  $ 20\text{ cm}$  long and $12\text{ cm}$ wide.     **What is the height of the water in Nemo's aquarium?**     $\text {cm}$

hints.content: Volume can be found using the formula $\purpleD{\text{Volume}}=\maroonD{\text{length}}\times \blueD{\text{width}}\times \greenD{\text{height}}$.

Let's plug in all the numbers we know:  $\purple{2{,}400}=\pink{20}\times\blue{12}\times\green{\, ?}$  $\purple{2{,}400}=240\times\green{\, ?}$  What number can we multiply by $240$ to get $\purple{2{,}400}?$
$\purple{2{,}400}=240\times\green{10}$  The height of the water in Nemo's aquarium is $\green{10}$ centimeters.

question.content: The sea turtle habitat at the zoo is made by connecting two large aquariums.   The first aquarium is $6\text { m}$  long, $4\text { m}$ wide, and $2\text { m}$ high.   The second aquarium is $8\text { m}$ long, $9\text { m}$ wide, and $3\text { m}$ high.   **How many cubic meters of space do the sea turtles have in their habitat?**       cubic meters

hints.content: First, let's find the volume of the two aquariums.  $\begin{align} \text{Volume }1&=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}\\\\ &=6\times4\times2\\\\ &= \blueD{48} \text{ cubic meters} \end{align}$  $\begin{align} \text{Volume }2&=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}\\\\ &=8\times9\times3\\\\ &= \maroonD{216} \text{ cubic meters} \end{align}$
Since the sea turtles can go in both aquariums, we need to add the volumes of the two aquariums.  $\blueD{48}+\maroonD{216}=\greenD{264}$
The sea turtles have $\greenD{264}$ cubic meters of space in their habitat.

question.content: I made a fort by connecting two boxes.   The first box is $5$ meters long, $9$ meters wide, and $9$ meters high.   The second box is $3$ meters long, $8$ meters wide, and $2$ meters high.   **How many cubic meters of space does my fort have?**       cubic meters

hints.content: First, let's find the volume of the two boxes.  $\begin{align} \text{Volume }1&=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}\\\\ &=5\times9\times9\\\\ &= \blueD{405} \text{ cubic meters} \end{align}$  $\begin{align} \text{Volume }2&=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}\\\\ &=3\times8\times2\\\\ &= \maroonD{48} \text{ cubic meters} \end{align}$
We need to add the volumes of the two boxes.  $\blueD{405}+\maroonD{48}=\greenD{453}$
My fort has $\greenD{453}$ cubic meters of space.

question.content: A rectangular-prism-shaped toy chest is $2 \text { m}$ by $1 \text { m}$ by $1 \text { m}$.    A shipping crate is packed with $18$ of these toy chests. There is no extra space in the crate.   **What is the volume of the crate?**     cubic meters

hints.content: First, let's find the volume of one toy chest.  $\begin{align} \text{Volume}&=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}\\\\ &=2\times1\times1\\\\ &= \blueD{2} \text{ cubic meters}\\\\ \end{align}$

There are $\maroonD{18}$ toy chests in the crate.   To find the volume of the shipping crate, we multiply the volume of one toy chest $(\blueD{2}$ cubic meters$)$ by the number of toy chests $(\maroonD{18})$.  $\blueD{2}\times\maroonD{18}=\greenD{36}$
The volume of the shipping crate is $\greenD{36}$ cubic meters.

question.content: Erin built a wooden box to hold hay on her farm.  The box is $3 \text { m}$ long,  $1 \text { m}$ wide, and $1 \text { m}$ high.    Hay costs $\$14$ per cubic meter.    **How much will it cost to completely fill the box with hay?**    $\$$

hints.content: First, let's find the volume of the box.  $V=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}$ $V=3\times1\times1$   $V= \blueD{3} \text{ cubic meters}$

It costs $\maroonD{\$14}$ for each cubic meter of hay.    So, we need to multiply $\pink{\$14}$ by the number of cubic meters $(\blueD{3})$ in the box.  $\blueD{3} \times \maroonD{\$14} = \greenD{\$42}$
It will cost $\greenD{\$42}$ to completely fill the box with hay.

question.content: My mom built a new sandbox that is $3 \text { m}$ long,  $2 \text { m}$ wide, and $1 \text { m}$ high for my sister and me.    Sand for the sandbox costs $\$4.50$ per cubic meter.    **How much will it cost to completely fill the sandbox with sand?**    $\$$

hints.content: First, let's find the volume of the sandbox.  $V=\text{length}\times \text{width}\times \text{height}$  $V=3\times2\times1$   $V= \blueD{6} \text{ cubic meters}$

It costs $\maroonD{\$4.50}$ for each cubic meter of sand.  So, we need to multiply $\maroonD{\$4.50}$ by the number of cubic meters $(\blueD{6})$ in the sandbox.  $\blueD{6} \times \maroonD{\$4.50} = \greenD{\$27}$
It will cost $\greenD{\$27}$ to completely fill the sandbox with sand.
